lines.text: Imagine... Dr. Beaumont keeping this heart pumping for over twenty years!
Wish he could do something about making your heart pump!

[Responding to Beaumont's questions while dying]
Leave the dead to their makers. The Lord, thy God is a jealous god.

[Feeling a sense of urgency]
But, John, what is death? Can't you put it into words? Tell me! Tell me! You must! what is death?
I think I can...
[after a pause]
After the shock...
Yes?
I seemed to feel...
Yes?
...peace and a...
[He dies]
[looking up to Heaven, while being led to the electric chair]
*He'll* believe me.

[as the crooked lawyer misses a shot on a pool table]
Straight shot and I missed it!
But you can't kill me for something I didn't do! You can't!
Last night I thought you were my friend. You took my life!

[Contemptuously]
I'm gonna take it again unless you got cat blood in yuh. No one's gonna bring you back this time.
You can't kill me again!

All I know is that for a short time the spirit of life left his body. Now, what happened during that transition? What effect did the experience of death have on his subconscious mind. Can he remember?
Well, it's rather a large order, doctor, and I'm afraid a bit beyond the province of law...
...and beyond the province of science too, but it's a challenge, and somewhere, I think, we'll find the key to all this.
If you do, I hope you'll let me know.

[Last lines. Comforting Nancy, who is sobbing over Ellman's death]
He's happier now.
It will never be known. The Lord thy God is a jealous God!
Why did you have me killed?
